g.text: relaxation between the top atomic Cu(410) interlayers
. On the other hand, ion scattering spectroscopy (ISS)
measurements show large contraction between the first few Cu(410) layers
the pattern of relaxation sequences, in broad scale, complement each other. For the case of Ag(410), previous
quantitative LEED (QLEED) analyses found no surface relaxation (neither expansion:
respect to the bulk-truncated values) of the first interlayer spacing, and a (
Embedded atom models for Ag(410) and Cu(410) show a sequence of contractions for the first, second, and
(FLAPW) calculations, in the framework of local density approximation (LDA) and generalized gradient approx-
imation (GGA) studies, of Cu(410) also show a sequence of contractions that continue from the first to the fourth
. The discrepancies in the theoretical and experimental results have been
attributed to LEED analyses done/limited to only three or four layers from the surface, and do not portray the
overall relaxation scenario as depicted by theoretical calculations
Here, we present results of our experimental study on the Cu(410) surface, using QLEED analyses. To get the
) curves, we considered slab thickness ranging from 24 to
64 atomic layers, with corresponding relaxed layers ranging from 8 to 32 atomic layers. We confirmed the con-
sistency of the results with Pendry reliability factors
0.2. In the following, we give a detailed discussion of the
relaxation (perpendicular and lateral displacements) of the surface atoms.
, we show a comparison of the interlayer spacing between the bulk-truncated Cu(410) (cf., Fig.
(lower panel)) and the QLEED-determined relaxed Cu(410) (Fig.
determined using 16 optimized relaxed layers, and the experimental
). We found that Cu(410) exhibits an alternating sequence of expansion (
), as compared to the bulk-truncated interlayer spacing (ca. 0.437 Å). In Table
we show the resulting interlayer relaxation and positions of the top 16 relaxed atoms relative to the bulk crystal.
To validate the results, we compare the interlayer spacings of
the terrace atoms of Cu(410), i.e., atoms along Cu(410)-[100] and their Cu(100) counterpart (cf., Fig.
). To define the first (topmost) interlayer spacing, we took the difference in the average positions
of the first group of four atoms, viz., (1, 2, 3, 4)
A layer, and that of the second group of four atoms, viz., (5,
B layer. We did the same for the next two groups of four atoms, viz., C and D layers. The results show
A-B contraction, B-C expansion, and no change in C-D (relative to the bulk-truncated (100) interlayer spacing
). This trend agrees with the surface layer relaxation of Cu(100)
the second layers of the Cu(100) contract relative to the bulk-truncated values, compensating for the lower coor-
dination number. On the average, the Cu(410)-[100] atoms also show similar (A-B) contraction.
(upper panel) Top and (lower panel) side view of the (
relaxed Cu(410). Dotted lines correspond to the positions of the corresponding atomic layers.
